topics.title: Choosing an Inverter for Your System
topics.content:
For a 12V system with 8× 280Ah batteries (26.9 kWh), size your inverter to your peak simultaneous load.

**Recommendations by load:**
- 2000W continuous: Renogy 2000W Pure Sine (~$200)
- 3000W continuous: Giandel 3000W (~$280)
- 5000W continuous: Aims Power 5000W (~$450)

**Rule:** Size to 1.25× your largest simultaneous load. Pure sine wave is required for sensitive electronics, motors, and appliances.

**12V note:** High-wattage inverters (3000W+) draw 250A+ from a 12V bank. Use short, thick cables (2/0 AWG or larger) and a proper fuse within 18 inches of the battery.

topics.title: Fusing & Wire Sizing
topics.content:
**Critical safety rule:** Every positive wire must be fused within 18 inches of the battery.

**Wire sizing guide (12V DC):**
| Current | Wire Size | Use Case |
|---------|-----------|----------|
| Up to 30A | 10 AWG | Small loads |
| Up to 60A | 6 AWG | Controller output |
| Up to 80A | 4 AWG | Controller (your AmpinVT) |
| Up to 150A | 2/0 AWG | Inverter |
| Up to 300A | 4/0 AWG | Large inverter |

**Your AmpinVT 150/80:** Use 4 AWG minimum on battery side, fused at 100A (ANL or MIDI fuse).

**Panel wiring:** Use 10 AWG for each string, rated for outdoor/UV exposure (USE-2 or PV wire).

topics.title: Battery Balancing
topics.content:
**Cell balance** is the difference in voltage between your highest and lowest battery/cell.

**Accu-Solar thresholds:**
- Normal: spread < 50mV
- Warning: spread 50–100mV
- Critical: spread > 100mV

**How to fix imbalance:**
1. **Passive balancing:** Your BMS does this automatically during charging — just let it run a full charge cycle
2. **Active balancer:** A $15–30 active balancer board continuously moves energy from high cells to low cells — highly recommended for 8-battery banks
3. **Manual equalization:** Disconnect the low battery, charge it individually to 14.6V, reconnect

**Prevention:** Always charge all batteries together, never mix old and new batteries in the same bank.

topics.title: Cold Weather & LiFePO4 Batteries
topics.content:
**LiFePO4 and cold temperatures:**

- **Discharge:** Safe down to -20°C (-4°F) — just reduced capacity
- **Charging:** Do NOT charge below 0°C (32°F) — causes permanent lithium plating damage

**Your system at 9°C (48°F):** Currently fine for charging. Watch for overnight temps dropping below freezing.

**Solutions for cold climates:**
1. **Self-heating BMS:** Some JBD BMS units have a heating pad — check your BMS app
2. **Insulated enclosure:** Foam insulation around battery bank retains heat from normal operation
3. **Low-temp cutoff:** Set your BMS to stop charging below 5°C as a safety margin

**Capacity loss:** At 0°C, LiFePO4 delivers ~80% of rated capacity. At -20°C, ~60%.

topics.title: Expanding Your System
topics.content:
**Adding more batteries:**
- Add in parallel (same voltage, more Ah)
- Match chemistry, age, and capacity — never mix old and new LiFePO4
- Each new battery needs its own BMS or use a shared BMS rated for the full bank
- Rebalance the bank after adding

**Adding more panels:**
- The EG4 6000EHV-48 has built-in MPPT rated up to 6000W PV input
- You can add up to ~20× 300W panels before hitting the EG4's limit
- Wire additional panels into the same 4S2P config or add a second PV string input

**Upgrading storage:**
- Add a second 4S2P string (4 more 12V batteries) in parallel with your existing bank
- Doubles capacity to 53.76 kWh @ 48V

topics.title: EG4 6000EHV-48 Hybrid Inverter
topics.content:
**Your inverter: EG4 6000EHV-48**

**Key specs:**
- Continuous output: 6000W AC
- Battery voltage: 48V nominal
- Max PV input: 500V, up to 6000W
- Built-in MPPT charge controller (replaces external controller)
- Max charge current: 120A
- Hybrid: can use solar, battery, and grid simultaneously

**Why this replaces the AmpinVT:**
The EG4 has MPPT built in — solar panels connect directly to the EG4's PV terminals. No separate charge controller needed.

**Solar wiring for EG4:**
- Your 4S2P array: ~74V Voc, ~32A — well within 500V limit ✅
- Connect MC4 cables from PV disconnect directly to EG4 PV+ and PV−

**First power-up:** Always use a pre-charge resistor (20–30Ω, 10W) across the DC breaker terminals for 10 seconds before flipping the breaker ON. This prevents capacitor inrush damage.

topics.title: 48V Battery Bank Wiring (4S2P)
topics.content:
**Your 8× 12V 280Ah batteries → 48V 560Ah bank**

**Wiring: 4S2P (4 in series, 2 strings in parallel)**

**String 1 (Batteries 1–4):**
- Neg 1 → Pos 2 → Neg 2 → Pos 3 → Neg 3 → Pos 4
- Free ends: Pos 1 (+48V) and Neg 4 (ground)
- Attach HC02 balancer 5-wire tap across all 4 batteries

**String 2 (Batteries 5–8):**
- Same series wiring as String 1
- Attach second HC02 balancer

**Joining at busbars:**
- Pos 1 and Pos 5 → each through a 150A Class T fuse → Positive busbar
- Neg 4 and Neg 8 → through 500A shunt → Negative busbar
- Positive busbar → 150A DC main breaker → EG4 battery positive
- Negative busbar → EG4 battery negative

**Result:** 48V nominal, 560Ah, 26.88 kWh total, ~21.5 kWh usable

topics.title: Pre-Charge Procedure (No Sparks!)
topics.content:
**Why pre-charge?** The EG4 inverter has large internal capacitors. Connecting a full battery bank instantly causes a massive inrush current — a loud pop, arc flash, and potential damage.

**Pre-charge resistor:** 20–30 Ohm, 10W (a $2 resistor from Amazon or any electronics store)

**Step-by-step power-up sequence:**
1. PV Disconnect: **OFF**
2. DC Main Breaker: **OFF**
3. Hold the resistor across both studs of the 150A DC Main Breaker (In and Out terminals)
4. Hold for **10 seconds** — capacitors charge slowly through the resistor
5. Flip the 150A DC Main Breaker **ON** (EG4 screen lights up silently — no pop)
6. Flip the 63A PV Disconnect **ON** — solar starts flowing
7. Press the EG4 power button

**Shutdown sequence (always do this order):**
1. PV Disconnect **OFF** first
2. Then DC Main Breaker **OFF**
3. Never disconnect battery while solar is charging — arcing will damage terminals

topics.title: HC02 Battery Equalizer / Balancer
topics.content:
**HC02 48V Battery Equalizer**

The HC02 actively moves energy between cells in a series string to keep all batteries at equal voltage — critical for long battery life in a 4S configuration.

**Wiring (5-wire tap):**
- Wire 1 → Negative terminal of Battery 1 (system ground of string)
- Wire 2 → Junction between Battery 1 and 2
- Wire 3 → Junction between Battery 2 and 3
- Wire 4 → Junction between Battery 3 and 4
- Wire 5 → Positive terminal of Battery 4 (top of string)

**One HC02 per string** — you need 2 total for your 4S2P bank.

**When it works:** Continuously while the bank is connected. No on/off switch needed.

**Target spread:** < 50mV between batteries. HC02 will correct up to ~200mV imbalance.

**LED indicators:** Green = balancing active, Red = fault (check connections)

topics.title: Safety Sequence for Startup and Shutdown
topics.content:
**Startup sequence:**
1. PV Disconnect: **OFF**
2. DC Main Breaker: **OFF**
3. Pre-charge resistor: **ON** (10 seconds)
4. 150A DC Main Breaker: **ON**
5. 63A PV Disconnect: **ON**
6. Press the EG4 power button

**Shutdown sequence:**
1. PV Disconnect: **OFF**
2. 150A DC Main Breaker: **OFF**
3. Never disconnect battery while solar is charging — arcing will damage terminals

systemContext: This is a real off-grid solar installation upgrading to 48V. The owner has 8x ECO-Worthy 12V 280Ah LiFePO4 batteries being rewired 4S2P for 48V/560Ah. The inverter is an EG4 6000EHV-48 hybrid with built-in MPPT. Solar is 8x 300W panels in 4S2P (~74V Voc, ~32A). Live BMS telemetry is connected via Bluetooth and MQTT. The system is actively running with real data visible in all dashboard tabs.
